page.title: 07GRETTON VILLAGE GREEN
page.content: The village green lies opposite to the Church and was a centre of the old village. On it can be found the stocks and whipping post - a reminder of past punishments for wrong-doers. These are surrounded by railings to protect them. The stocks were last used in 1858 for their legitimate purpose - apparently to hold someone who had drunk too much alcohol. The village green also houses the war memorial. Each year in November a festival of remembrance is held, and wreathes are laid in honour of the people who died in the two world wars of 1914 and 1939. Each spring, daffodils planted by the schoolchildren bloom on the green. A bench has been sited here so that people may rest, look at the Church and admire the magnificent Welland valley.
